description:
Chili oil fish. The best.

They are also pretty quick with service, overall friendly.

Need to try more, but also love the chili oil wontons
author: Ellie M.

description:
We'd planned for dinner at San Tung, but of course the line was out the door and way too long for us to wait. My friend recommended China North Dumpling, and as it was just a short drive away, we decided it would be a good second choice. 

For a party of 4, we ordered the pig ear appetizer, napa cabbage and pork dumplings, the sichuan boiled fish, and the deep fried eggplant. 

The pig ear appetizer was actually quite delicious. The texture was almost like the squid in a cold cut platter. I like that it was mixed in with red and green bell peppers, which made it super refreshing. 

Everything else was pretty good, but my favorite was the deep fried eggplant. The eggplant is skinned and battered before deep frying, giving it a texture similar to a well done potato fry. I probably could have devoured the whole plate by myself! :9

Overall, it was a selection of guilty pleasure eats, but while delicious at the time, I definitely felt the (gross, bloated) effects of the food hours later. That being said, this would definitely not be a restaurant I would frequent, however if I ever have a craving for greasy kung pao chicken, I know exactly where to go!
author: Sherry L.

description:
My last (LAST) meal here was really, really bad.

I'm pretty easy to please.  Give me something salty and greasy and I'm happy.  But give me Chow Fun that is mushy and bland (literally no seasoning added)...and I can't help but wonder, "how can anybody mess up Chow Fun!"

I ordered my sweet and sour pork (and clearly asked, "will you make it with pork?") and I got sweet and sour chicken... OK, I can forgive that.  But the dish was flavorless, soggy, and bland. It was as if the chef thought I was on a heart-healthy diet and made it without any salt or oil.

I also ordered a Chow-Mein dish that was disappointing.  Once again, all I can think is, "how can anyone mess-up something so simple!"

I asked the people dining at the tale next to us how their food was.  They said, "There is no flavor.  The fried spare ribs taste like they were boiled."

When the check came, I very kindly and gently told our server why I was disappointed with our meal.  She was not apologetic and made no attempt to remedy the situation.

I believe in supporting the small businesses in my neighborhood...but life is too short to get meals like this.  No more China North for my family.
author: Izzy B.

description:
Despite the ample portion and very reasonable pricing for lunch, suffice to say I won't be returning. Taste was average as was the dish, a bland gravy covering chunks of half meat, half fat atop wilted or overcooked bok choi.

What bothered me was the staff. After served the single server disappeared, forcing guests to approach the team making the dough for dumplings to find someone to gather the bills. The person found didn't understand how-to use the chip card reader so she began telling guests, including myself that our cards were declining.

They're lucky I had just enough cash to cover the bill. When I told the employee to just swipe the card she gave me a dull stare.

No tip for you.
author: Frank L.

description: My comfort food for those rainy, fatty days. Boneless fried chicken - check. Chive pancakes - check. Either wontons or some form of dumpling - check. Garlic vinegar sauce - check. Extra chopsticks so they don't think it's all for myself - check.
author: Jonathan Y.

description: The food is great. Servers will get you whatever you need. Makes great leftovers and you can even order frozen dumplings to keep in the freezer at home when you don't feel like going out. This is my go to affordable dinner spot.
author: Sean R.

description:
Food:

Haven't been here for maybe a year or two.  My favorite dish is still the spicy red sauce dumplings that swims in the sauce.  I used to come here for just dumplings.  The chives with prawns is good but I like it pan fried then dipped in vinegar.  

Recently I've tried the dinner dishes that goes with rice which I thought was mediocre.  it doesn't give me a wow factor.  I've tried the lion head meatballs which are flavorful with the sauce but not wow inside the meatball (have had it better elsewhere).  The tofu seems nice and colored but wasn't spectacular in flavor either.  My favorite of all the dishes were probably the (non-spicy) eggplant dish.  They only have 3 types of eggplants.  If you ask for non-spicy that's the one I like.. I remember trying their dry one before and it was NOT good.  The last dish I've tried is the "saliva chicken" if you say it in Chinese.  It's a cold served chicken but the flavor here isn't as good as other places i've had it from so overall I'd give the dinner dishes a 3 star.  and a 5 star for my favorite dumpling dish and  around a 3 and a half for the other dumplings.  

Service: 

From what I remember there appears to be trouble getting the attention of the servers.  English isn't understood really well for the most part as long as you could point to the list of food or pictures you're ok, but they probably have to fish someone in there to speak English to you if you need to ask for recommendations or have questions.  I think selective workers speak Cantonese and more so speak Mandarin so if Language is a struggle for you then, try to be sure of your food selections prior to ordering.  They also make mistakes too which is normal , but from my experience they made it sound like we changed our minds on the order when it came out instead of them taking the order down wrong.  No apologies either.  

I didn't have too much expectation for service so I wasn't too disappointed, therefore the overall score for food and service it averages out to about 3/5 star for me so far :)  Hope to see changes in the future.  I'd be back for the dumplings.
author: Juila L.

description:
Solid food, low prices, and quick service. Checks all the boxes of a good place for an easy dinner in the Sunset! 

Good vegetarian options, especially relative to some of the other restaurants in the area. We had veggie chowmein, veggie fried rice, and veggie dumplings and they were all good (especially the dumplings) and came out relatively quickly. There were three of us and this was the perfect amount of food (for less than $30 total, great prices!).

Food isn't amazing enough that I would trek to the Sunset for it, but if you're in the neighborhood, this is a good choice!
author: Audrey S.

description:
This has got to be the nastiest dumpling place I've ever been to. First off, the bathroom was stinky and disguising (not because of someone business) but because it needs cleaning. I am so glad we didn't order much. We ordered the Wonton w/ Spicy oil, beef pancake, Chives w/ pork dumpling, and XLB. 

The wonton w/ spicy oil was the best because it was drenched in sauce. The meat in the XLB, dumpling, and pancake was so strong. Tasted like it was never cleaned. It was so gross, we didn't finish our food. The aftertaste linger in our mouth for such a long time even after we drank cups of tea. 

Service: We waited forever to get spoons + our check. NEVER coming back.
author: Annie Y.

description:
Super quick and straight to the point review!

Salt and pepper chicken always! 

Chicken wings had a good crunch but we're a little too salty for me.

Stuffed pancakes with garlic vinegar sauce is highly recommended.

They are known for their dumplings so try some!

Everything is delicious. Great place to go for some Chinese comfort food. Service isn't that great, but that's pretty typical at Chinese restaurants! Give it a try!
author: Rachelle T.

description: Wow as someone who's been to countless dumpling houses in both SF and China I have to say this place is a gem. Clean interior with friendly staff and nice grandma characters :) we went ham on the menu, and oh my god I am raving about this Szechuan fried chicken, House special pork pancakes and Shanghai chow mein. The dishes are SOLID and delicious - I am stuffed. Definitely catch me coming back
author: Grace O.

description: Big portions and cheap prices. We had beef chow fun and sauteed green beans. Both were fine but neither was very special. The chown fun was kinda bland. The green beans were much better.
author: James A.

description: This place is not as good as it used to be. The green onion pancakes that I liked so much before are now bland and have little to no green onions in them. They basically are just taste like plain dough. I would not order them again...they really are disappointing.
author: Celena C.

description:
Another classic sunset district 3 star restaurant. There's something about Chinese food in the sunset district I can't exactly describe, but once you've experienced a few places you'll start noticing it's different in style and taste than Chinese food elsewhere in the city. 

For food, we got the egg flower soup- pretty good, light and with carrots and peas, like ones from a bag in the frozen aisle. Didn't mind them, though.

The braised pork looked dark and deliciously glazed and braised in the menu, but when we received it it fell below expectation. The sauce was brown... not dark like soy sauce. It didn't have the classic soy braised pork taste. The sauce also penetrated the bok choy underneath, making it oily and not super palatable.

Unfortunately don't have good things to say about the pig ears either- definitely one of the worse ones I've had, and again, I think it's because the sauce they used wasn't the typical red chili sauce. The sauce looked paler and tasted more bland.

The dumplings though, they got right. It takes a while to cook, but they're plump, juicy and a big portion of meat filling.

I've been here one other time, and the chicken and mushroom was delicious and tasty but was full of tiny chicken bones. Their beef noodle soup was really not good either, the meat was pretty tough. So all in all, the highlight was... the egg drop soup. Really?! -__-
author: Ke C.

description:
It's been 3 years since I last ate here and I had fond memories. Food still tastes great! And now that typical Chinese dishes are around $9 in the area, what you get here for the price is some pretty damn good food. 

Ordered:
M1. Crispy Salt & Pepper Chicken - like the Chinese version of popcorn chicken but spicier and damn delicious. You also get a heaping pile of quality meats, not just a bunch of batter. $9.55

M26. Green Onion Satay Beef - I'm a satay fan and this dish does not disappoint. All of the flavors are on point. Beef was tender and there wasn't a disportionate amount of onions. So good. $9.95

M12. Leaves Spareribs - skip this dish
I was intrigued by the name of this dish and when I asked what this was, the waiter who spoke limited English couldn't really explain it. He was able to point to another dish and said it had the same sauce. Well the dish is basically braised (and chopped) spareribs with bell peppers. Why is this called Leaves Spareribs?? The spareribs were surprisingly tender but it didn't have an amazingly distinctive flavor like the other 2 dishes we ordered. $10.95 - would not recommend this

Overall I loved eating here. Parking is mostly all metered in the area. $2 for an hour. Be prepared to park a couple of blocks away.
author: Cathrin P C.

description:
Pretty solid place for a quick and easy meal! I live right around the corner and love coming here randomly. 

They have one dish that I love and want to share with others. The spicy fried fish. It is to die for!! 

The fish is so crispy on the outside and tender on the inside. There are also pockets of salt and garlic and flavor that explode in your mouth when you eat it! 

They are going to know me as 'The Fish Guy' in a matter of time. Their dumplings are also good and their dishes have a nice variety of vegetables unlike other Chinese restaurants that just have protein and carbs in their rice or noodle dish.
author: Jonathan W.

description:
I have been wanting to bring hubby by for weeks, seeing all these great reviews on other food posts I belong to.....

We crossed the Bay Bridge for this, terrible mistake, never again....

If I could give zero stars, I would....wait was long, service was damn slow....

We ordered xiao long bao, it was a thick skin with barely any juice, that is a no go, they charge like 7 or 8 bucks for a few pieces of thick skin with ground pork....terrible

Shanghai noodles were way too greasy, barely any veggies, how cheap can they be....

Don't bother
author: Leslie Y.

description:
Why does my review for this place keep on getting deleted?!.  I'm going to save my review in my google docs and everytime yelp deletes it i'll add it back.  

This is my favorite place to come to in SF.  I mind, i hate looking for parking, but this place is worth it.  Their dumplings and noodles are made fresh here.  You can see it behind the counter.  So at times it does take time for the food to come out.  I think it's all worth waiting for.  Here's what i love to order 

Pot stickers- perfectly pan fried and i love how big and juicy the dumplings are
Corn and Chicken dumplings-  I normally get this steamed.   This dumpling is super juicy and sweet and you can taste just how fresh the corn and chicken is
Sticky rice roll- do you know how hard is it to find this dish?  I'm so glad they have it here, but it's only on weekends.  This reminds me of the dishes in asia so much
Napa cabbage with chicken dumplings- i get this on pan-fried and it is still really juicy and flavorful
Shanghai rice cake -  I like to order this dish with napa cabbage.  They don't skip on the ingredients.  They give you lots of veggies and pork.  
Minced pork noodle with soy bean paste- Like i said before, the noodles you can taste are freshly made and they aren't the thin noodles, they are the wider noodles which i like
Sizzling plate black bean sauce chicken-  it's a pretty big portion and there's a good amount of flavor in this dish.  
Soy milk-  this is freshly made and i highly recommend it 

The service here is always great and i will make it as one of my favorite places to eat in SF
author: Belinda C.

description: Great place. Parking going to be a little tough the service is good food smells delicious we had the Cabbage lamb soup and it tastes great. I'm glad they have great pictures because sometimes I have trouble ordering the food. This is supposed to be a northern China Restaurant but they seem to have a lot of what I consider cantonesee style food they must be catering to the ocal population
author: M L.

description:
Ordered for to go, zucchini lamb dumplings, fried little yellow fish, and soured napa cabbage with lamb soup.
The soup was ok, but they obviously gave me the wrong dumpling which is not acceptable because I'm Muslim and they gave me pork dumpling. The yellow fish was very thick breaded. I've had so many fried little yellow fishes in many restaurants, this one is the worst. 
Very bad experience overall. =(
author: Lulu W.

description:
My boyfriend and I were looking for good Shanghai dumpling restaurant in the Sunset District and decided to try this place out. We came a little bit before the lunch rush on Saturday and we were seated right away. 

The menu is pretty robust. There's a lot of different options and the classic dishes are there too - green onion pancakes, shanghai dumplings, pan fried buns, etc. Overall, I felt the food was just ordinary. 

Chive and Pork Dumpling: These were my favorite! There was a lot of filling inside and the skin was just the right thickness. The filling was juicy and they were delicious! 

Shanghai Dumpling: These definitely had the most meat filling I've ever seen, but that also made it dry and not as soupy and light. 

Noodles in Black Bean Sauce: This was a very large portion and I liked the hand pulled thick noodles they used, but the sauce was not very flavorful and was on the blander side. This is usually my favorite dish, but this one didn't cut it. 

It did it's job for a quick lunch. I would definitely stick with the dumplings next time and maybe try a noodle soup dish to get a taste of something different.
author: Kelly N.

description:
I was in the city and craving dumplings, so my friend took me to China North Dumpling. So glad I found out about this place! Fresh dumplings made daily, which you can taste and see (open kitchen). We tried their pork and chives dumplings, and salt and pepper chicken. Both were my favorites, and that chicken was fiyaaaah! Coming back next time with my husband  :)

Side note: Service is a bit slow, and it took forever to get water or for them to take my money =/ But I guess that's typical for any Asian restaurant. If you can look passed that, the food is worth the visit.
author: Ivana Y.

description: You can literally see the workers making the skins and fillings for the dumplings that are amazing! They take a little longer to get, granted that they're fresh & handmade, but definitely worth the wait. During my visit, my family and I also got the squid appetizer (which was very refreshing), the chicken in chili oil (a bit smaller than expected, but still good with a good kick of spice), the pork xiao long bao (one of my favorites), pork dumplings (you can get them fried or steamed and also so so good), and fish with tofu (it was quite a large dish but was a little lackluster in taste).
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
Was in the neighborhood (unplanned) around lunch time on a Sunday so decided to stop by this place for food. 

Got the green onion pancakes (http://bit.ly/2cDKfw2)
I liked the texture on these and definitely think it was the best dish of the meal. Flavor wise, it's a bit bland. You couldn't really taste the green onions (not that many) and it could have used a bit more salt. I just dipped it in the chili oil at the table (spicier than usual btw) and the sauces from other dishes.

Pork belly with boy choy (http://bit.ly/2d0cgAm)
Got these because I wanted a dish with actual vegetables so just picked one based on the photos in the menu. The sauce was just okay - and that's generally what makes this dish.

Wonton with spicy oil (http://bit.ly/2cEKaLO)
These have mustard on the bottom... which really threw me off. They were the worst wonton with spicy oil I've ever had. Meat kind of bland, mustard with peanut butter was not a great combination, and the sauce was reallly watery. 

The meal I had here was just okay. Definitely didn't have anything that would make me want to come back.
author: Lily L.

description: Came here on a whim after work and had the sautéed string beans (3/5) and Napa cabbage and pork steamed dumplings (2/5). Was very disappointed by the dumplings. I was excited because I saw them being freshly hand rolled in front of me, but they came out too salty and not tasty at all. Furthermore, the dumpling was majority skin and the skin was super thick. Would much rather go to Taraval for either Dumpling Kitchen or Kingdom of Dumpling (personal favorite).
author: Karina T.

description: A hidden gem in the central Sunset. They're known for their dumplings, but they should be known for their fried rice and noodles! They are the best I've had in SF. One thing to note - they are cash only, so be mindful of that when you come. Prices are fantastic - especially for SF. Service is quick. Also great for vegetarians like myself!
author: Casondra P.

description: Not too shabby. I've been here about five times with my dad. Pot stickers. Soy gaiw or however you wanna spell it. Dumplings. Nicely made and fried or steamed. Not too greasy. Good flavors with or without your hot sauce or vinegar.  Fried rice. Shanghai style dishes. Have tried them all but will come back again. Service with a smile.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
SERVICE: 3/5
FOOD: 5/5 
CLEANLINESS: 4/5

I was pleasantly surprised by this place and I wouldn't have even known about this place even existed lol thank God my brother and family were on the hunt for a quick bite to eat before we sent off my sister and in law back home. 

PARKING:
Meters everywhere on the street. Unless you want to spend 30 minutes to drive to a neighborhood and walk here; your best bet is to pay for parking. 
$2.25/hr. Takes coins and card. 

SERVICE: 
Nothing to complain about and also nothing to rave about either. Not that many people there during the time so we got what we asked for quickly. 

FOOD: 
We ordered a lot and the portions were plentiful too. Out of everything we ordered, their sesame chicken was a winner for me. Tried their xiao long bao, very flavorful and a must get if you come here. Pricing seemed reasonable, considering that there was 10 plates, the bill came shy under $100. 

OVERALL:
Keeping this place under my Yelp belt and I'm definitely coming back.
author: Grace Anne D.

description:
Neighborhood places always pique my interest.
Is that place any good?
The menu sounds interesting.
On a recent weeknight, a friend needing a favor met me here for dinner.  Wanting to finish watching a Warriors' road game on TV, we met here around 8 pm.  The dining room had only four filled tables so we can the pick of tables, opting for one near the window.  We waited briefly for another friend before ordering and said friend arrived when the second plate of food was served.  Here's what we shared:

1) Northern homemade colorful mix (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=J6JHHF1I8c3LOF1JsP57IA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Very colorful presentation and flavors were pretty good.  Just a notch below Great China in Berkley in terms of quality.  Nice to see this offered someplace not needing me to drive across a bridge.

2) Chive dumplings (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=LLhKurwJagJ0BHUGBJ-hSw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Probably the best dish from our menu.  The pastry was served piping hot as the skin had a nice chewy crisp texture.  The filing of chives and rice noodles were flavored on point.

3) XLB (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=tneyGwKsjm8cFETQy2fN5Q&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Decent rendition of the dumplings as the skin weren't too thick.  Wished there was a little more soup in the dumplings.  Generously sized and nine to an order.

4) Dry fried chicken wings (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=BEa1pacYDDtxBl6sXL8kYQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Visually appealing with a good crunch to the batter.  The flavor was just a bit off with more of a tangy than sweet flavor here.

5) Beef noodle soup (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=VP8r_kzBkQsyS_oDTTOVoQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Again, very large portions and no shortage of beef here.  The meat is a bit on the chewy side, but it is lean and had decent flavors.  

Three of us shared the above food and finished most of it.  There were leftovers of the chive dumpling and beef noodle soup which I saved for a future meal.  There was only one waitress working the dining room, but not sure whether it was due to our timing.  
Was it the best?  No, I wouldn't put it in that league.  
However, if you have a craving for dumplings or noodles while in the neighborhood, this is certainly a good option.  I definitely would tag this as a destination place.  
Be warned, there was a health department warning message when I pulled up this business.  Nothing looked alarming while we were dining, but, if you are squeamish about this, you might seek another place.
author: Mike C.

description:
Best homemade noodles I have ever eaten! I had the Shanghai Style Chow Mein and it was incredible! 
My 8 year old said "this is the best place to eat in the world!"
Not only is it delicious but it is very reasonably priced! Definitely will be returning!
author: Stacie C.

description: Probably, one of the best Northern Style Chinese Napa Cabbage sauerkraut soup（酸菜白肉湯）I've had in North America. The Chive Pocket/box(s)（韭菜盒子） is a bit on the sweet side for some reasons. Dumplings are excellent but I found the wrapping skin a bit too thick side. Otherwise, a great cheep eat for quality food. Friendly staff too which is a big plus.
author: Teahuis H.

description:
Consistently fast, friendly delivery. Some star dishes include the wontons in spicy oil, fried rice, and noodle soup with pork and preserved veggies. The dumplings and noodles are too doughy/thick for me, but some people like it that way. 

Portions are always generous, and price is fair. Interesting menu selection, but has all the standard fare as well.
author: Sarah H.

description:
China North Dumpling is great because 1) they deliver 2) they have family specials. And for the two of us, family special means a hearty meal with leftovers for another hearty meal the next day.

The family special is a good staple for solid Chinese food--you can't go wrong, even though the names of the dishes may sound mundane like "ginger with pork" or the endearingly Engrish name "leaves spareribs". The fish with black bean sauce is my favorite, with a decent amount of fish stir-fried in bold flavors of garlic and black bean. (As a kid I never liked black bean sauce because I thought it looked like bugs, but the boo converted me.)

We've also been to the actual restaurant and tried their Northern China specialties:
- Beef pancake: Tasty, but very small
- Northern style homemade colorful mixed noodles (yes that's the name): Not bad, though I always find this dish to be quite vinegary. Good option if you want to be adventurous.
- Dumpling: Honestly I find dumplings in SF to be all pretty good. (It's the XLB that distinguishes skillz!)

The verdict? Even though the restaurant is called China North Dumpling, I think their Northern Chinese cuisine options are just okay. I am a fan of the family specials of standard Chinese food + delivery (+ Netflix at home!) It's the little things.
author: Edna C.

description: This is one of the best Chinese place in town!!! Best dumplings! Always get the FRIED chive and pork dumplings, rice cake, crispy salt and pepper chicken.  Me and babe are so happy every time.  We come almost every two weeks. Super good!!!
author: Bobbi B.

description: I was craving dumplings and decided to try this place out because it was super close to my apartment... and I'm so glad I did! I ordered the Seafood Fried Rice and the Napa Cabbage with Pork Dumplings. The fried rice was okay, it was nothing special (something you can easily get anywhere) but the dumplings were delicious!! It was not dry and it had a lot of flavor. Another great thing is that they're freshly made! The service wasn't terrible considering there were only two servers. I'm definitely bringing my BF here next time and can't wait to try their other items on their menu.
author: Vanni Layne A.

description:
COCKROACHES are to be expected at most Chinese restaurants, but not seeing them vs seeing them while you're eating takes the dining experience to a whole different level. 

We were sitting there enjoying the oh so delicious food when my mom noticed a cockroach crawling on the wall. We were pretty grossed out and told the waitress. She called another waitress over to kill it and proceeded to apologize. 2 min later there was another, this time they called the chef out, with his apron on, he came out to address the situation. He walked up, took a look and killed it with his bare hands. Then he walked back in to the kitchen I'm assuming to continue cooking. Ummmm I hope he washed his hands. They gave us a 15% discount and said, "sorry." Ughhhh damn it, the food here is sooo good too... but I just can't get over the chef killing the roach with his bare hands and then returning to duty...
author: Mrs. S.

description:
XLB were dry, no soup in some and most had too little. However, the noodle dishes were great. They make their noodles in house. Salt and pepper chicken wings were crispy and flavorful. One of the better ones I've had.

Service was fine. Parking in this area sucked. 

Would come back for the wings and noodles. Might try other dumplings but would skip XLB.
author: Andy W.

description: My sister and I stumbled upon this place and we are so glad we tried it! The food here is northern style chinese food...lots of noodles and dumplings, all freshly made in house. I tried their dumpling soup noodle and it was delicious! They have an open kitchen in the back and I even saw them make dumplings fresh!
author: Tina S.

description:
A family run Chinese restaurant in the San Francisco Sunset Noriega Street area.  Specializes in dumpling. (No duh?)
Their menu is big and crosses many genres, not a good sign.

 Picks:
Green Onion Pancake ($6.50) much more expensive than usual, but thicker and more substantial.  Could use more flavor.

Shanghai Rice Cakes ($7.95) were decent with good sized rice cakes and nice shredded pork.

Sauteed String Beans ($8.25) were cooked with lots of onions.  Unusual but a decent version.

Frozen Xiao Long Bao Soup Dumplings are sold here. ($8.95 for 10) We ordered some to try later.

Just OK:
Cumin Lamb ($11.55) was reasonable but not great.  A bit greasy and low on heat and flavor.

Would not reorder:
None

Overall - Good
Food - Good
Decor - Good
Service - Good
Value - Good

Would we come back - Maybe
author: Ellen H.

description: I would recommend getting the green beans, the sweet and sour chicken, and the dumplings. Our waitresses were quick and good service. There's better food out there, I think I would only come here if I lived near here and was lazy to go somewhere else.
author: Kendrick K.

description:
I had a really good experience with the employees and food from China North Dumpling. 
I had ordered delivery on a lazy night through yelp and my order was confirmed quickly. I was given about a 40 minute wait time for the food to arrive. When it was on its way there was a mix up with the address (my fault) and a very nice and kind woman from the restaurant called me promptly to clear things up. The delivery guy was now on his way but he still couldn't find it. She stayed on the phone with me translating from me to him calmly and graciously. I eventually found the delivery guy and apologized and he was also very nice and gracious. 
The dumplings were fresh and juicy and the chow mein noodles were delicious. I will definitely order from here again.
author: Jenna B.

description: Delicious! Food was very good - super yum General Tso and I had the chive and pork dumplings, also great. It took a while for our order to be taken - be prepared to flag down the wait staff as that seems the best way to not have to wait very long. Food came out relatively quickly after ordering though. I would definitely recommend!
author: Laura D.

description:
I'm a bit surprised by some of the reviews here but I guess it's a classic case of Order The Right Things. As the name of the restaurant would suggest, order dumplings. But do NOT get the xlb (that's a Shanghai/HK staple, not a Northern Chinese specialty).

Do get the jiaozi, a whole list of which can be found on the first page of their menu. They are able to make most of the jiaozi boiled or pan fried. My personal preference has always been shuijiao over guotie; my favorites here are the pork & cabbage and the shrimp & chives (the classics, baby!). I love that they serve black vinegar instead of soy sauce because that really is the superior way to enjoy dumplings :)

The noodles here are hand pulled and I am a huge fan of their beef noodle soup. I think it may be my second favorite in the entire Bay Area thus far (there's a couple places near Parkside I may have to try first though). 

Their best non-dumpling dish, however, is probably is their braised eggplant. I always take people here to try this and they're always surprised that what they're eating is eggplant! Even non eggplant-fans may like this and it's always a favorite among our vegetarian friends. There's no words to describe the texture or flavor--except that it's ridiculously delicious!

Maybe my standards are different than most non-Chinese, but I've always found the service here to be good. Not stellar but definitely better than most of your average Chinese restaurants. If you dine-in, you also get unlimited amounts of salted peanuts and kimchi as a free appetizer. I've ordered takeout from here many times as well and never had issues.
author: Tiffany H.

description: Huge portions and reasonable prices. We had plenty of leftovers even after stuffing ourselves full. If in the area and I were craving dumplings, I would definitely drop by for a meal.
author: W A.

description:
I love this place for what it is, authentic Asian food with generous portions and a good price point.

The pork and chives dumplings were moist and they did not skimp on the meat. I like how juicy the dumplings were. Every bite left dumpling juices falling on to my plate.

The beef fried rice was really great. Not greasy at all, and with a good balance of veggies, eggs, and beef.

The salt and pepper spareribs had plenty of garlic flavor and was a bit greasy. The meat was exceptionally tender.

I will come here again to try other things on their huge menu.
author: Kevin T.

description:
Northern Chinese dumpling means the skin or wrap is thicker.  But it's filling stick to your bones good.

Had pot sticker, shrimp child dumping and little dragon dumpling aka xlb for those in the know.
All juicy and filling.

They make their own dough here and have quality ingredients.  

Soup was pickled cabbage, spare ribs and glass noodles.  Massive bowl so good that I could not finish.   Great bang for your buck.  And best of all a small mom and pops operation.

This is my 3rd trip here and will be back for more!
author: David H.

description:
Food was decent, albeit a little small on the portion for an Asian restaurant. I'm still not sure if we just misread the menu or was served the wrong dish but our cold appetizer of cauliflower had everything but cauliflower. It was still very yummy though - cold cucumbers tossed with bean curd and roasted peanuts covered in chili oil...yum yum yum!

As for our entrees, we ordered two types of noodles...both were pretty much the same with different noodle types. Garnishes were few and far in between so basically, we were just eating two types of noodles tossed in soy sauce. Hm. And though the steamed dumplings were pretty good, it was disappointing that they didn't serve it with the ginger/vinegar garnish. They only had a little spout of vinegar that you could dispense for yourself.

Lastly, this was more personal preference but because we sat on the adjacent space (the additional room) there was less of a presence from the waitresses. Another table that sat with us constantly went behind the counter to get more of the little "appetizers" - pickled vegetables and roasted peanuts. That's really kind of a cleanliness concern for me. I really doubt it was meant to be help yourself.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
1st time here & tasted pretty good but need to be patience for the dishes to come. I ordered the following:

-Green Onion Pancake $5.95 (Very Good)
-Northern Style Homemade Colorful Mixed $11.95 (Good)

*Friendly Server
*Need to be patience 
*Accept Cards (min. $15)
author: Wendy L.

description:
Service: typical Chinese restaurant service. They'll come and ask you what you want. They understand English and the menu had pictures so it's not hard to place your order. 

Food: a bit of a szechuan flare in their food so it's great if you enjoy a little heat in your meal! They have an entire section for their dumpling selection so it's probably worth ordering some! Try their spicy soup noodles too ( any of them!)
author: Greg Y.

description:
Shredded beef roll =  Thinly sliced beef with equally thinly sliced cucumber in a pancake, which was delicious. $7.95

Shredded potato spicy = If you're expecting the hot-and-sour potatoes...this isn't it but this is equally as delicious with numbing spiciness. $5.55 

Green onion pancake = good but more doughy than we'd like it. $5.95

Fennel pork dumplings (opted for steamed) = good and juicy. 12 pieces for $8.45

Chive and chicken dumplings (pan fried) = excellent and juicy. 12 pieces for $7.95 (I ordered napa cabbage with chicken but they served us this instead.) 

Wonton spicy oil = plenty to share and spicy with a mustard kick. $6.95

Salt and pepper chicken wings = hot, salty, peppery and hit the spot. 8 pieces for $7.95

Vegetable Shanghai noodles = perfect thick cut noodles with crunchy vegetables. $7.55

Mushu Pork = cabbage, wood ear mushrooms, carrots, onions, scallions and julienned pork with pancakes.  $8.95

Service = friendly and polite. 

Noise = loud. Perhaps it was because we were seated near the kitchen but they were banging stuff around.  

Prices = reasonable. Late lunch/early dinner for 5 came out to $73.13, with leftovers.
author: Fannie S.

description:
I recently came with some coworkers as a group of 4 so I got to try a few dishes. The restaurant itself is bigger than I expected, with a side door leading to an extended section to the restaurant. The table sizes varied, so this can be a convenient location for parties of all sizes to gather for a quick lunch or dinner.

Dishes I got to try:
Napa cabbage and pork dumplings: These were rather good! The skin was a tad thick but the juices inside were fantastic. I would definitely recommend giving these a try. Get them pan fried for a little more flavor!
Special Beef Noodle Soup: I was rather disappointed by this dish. The noodles were soggy, the soup was bland, and the overall execution was poorly done. 
Shanghai Style Chow Mein: I rather enjoyed this dish - the flavors are a little on the heavier side though so it's a little salty and oily. The noodles are very well done however.
String Bean: This was done as you might expect - nothing surprising about it but nothing disappointing either.
Hot & Spicy Boiled Fish: Despite how big this bowl was, ours barely held any fish in it! As a heads up, the overall dish is not as spicy as it looks. Avoid the chilis by scraping the majority of it off of your pieces of fish and vegetables, and it makes for a pleasant heat.

Overall, I will probably be back to give a few of the other dishes a try. My overall impressions were that the dishes were average, but being close to my current workplace it is definitely convenient. Prices are fairly reasonable and portion sizes are quite good, so you can definitely get full off of one dish here. I enjoyed coming as a party however just for more variety to the dishes.
author: Michael L.

description: People are nice, service is okay. Food is below average. Braised beef noodle was ordered, appearance wasn't attractive. Meat weren't tendered. Simply disappointing!
author: William Q.

description:
Good food, terrible service. 

Actually, I should say service was non-existent. Their waitresses must be paid to focus on packing take out & delivery orders ONLY, because that's all the 3 of them did. And when they were finally away from the counter, they walked around the restaurant with their eyes to the ground. It felt like we needed to use red flares to flag someone down. And it wasn't even busy! We came for a late dinner at 8pm Mother's Day eve. We had a total of 9 dishes but unfortunately I don't remember them all because we were all focused on the overwhelming lack of service. 

The XLB was delicious. There was a lot of broth inside, and the size is great for the price. Also loved their Shanghai Thick Noodles. The only 2 complaints were the green onion pancake: some pieces had way too much green onions and other pieces had just specks of green onions; Salt & pepper chicken wings should be renamed to Salty chicken wings. While the wings were crisp on the outside and juicy on the inside, the amount of salt was overpowering, and there was no zing from any peppers. 

Price was very reasonable. $82 for 9 dishes. The food is good, but unfortunately I don't think I will be back again after this second time. I'd rather pay delivery & tip the driver than tip the wait staff here. Now I see why they get so many take-out and delivery orders.
author: Florence S.

description:
Generous portions and well priced Chinese food.  Our family loves ordering the fried salt and pepper fish, the potstickers and dumplings, the Shanghai noodles, etc.  Definitely mostly hits and I love that they have high chairs, so it makes it very family friendly for those of us with little ones.

I definitely go back and do take-out as well.  Very yummy!
author: Christine K.

description:
By far my favorite place to get dumplings and green onion pancakes! The chicken and mushroom soup and garlic noodles were good as well. All Inexpensive! It smells great with all things cooking. 
Be careful of when you come, sometimes street parking is hard to find!
author: Tiffany N.

description:
After reading some of these negative reviews, I think Susy C.'s review is spot on - those people just came in with the wrong expectations.  Although they do offer a few dishes from other Chinese cuisines, China North Dumpling (as its name suggests) focuses mainly on Northern Chinese dishes.  What does that entail, exactly?  Noodles and dumplings galore!

While it may be disappointing for some not to see a favorite like Xiao Long Baos on the menu, China North has plenty of other great dishes to offer - about 160+ in total?  It's impressive that they can offer such an extensive range of appetizers, cold dishes, noodles, vegetable/tofu dishes, soups, seafood, and, of course, numerous types of dumplings (other than XLB).

-- GREEN ONION PANCAKE...$4.95
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/china-north-dumpling-san-francisco?select=1g75lAzSyjmMm7P2jSh3bg#hqTKQ18DOMPJXD0N6zHPpw)
It was thicker than I typically prefer (thin and crispy), but the outside had a nice crust.  The center was pretty good too, as it was slightly chewy and not bready, and the fresh green onions helped to add a lot of great flavor.

-- NAPA CABBAGE WITH PORK DUMPLING...$6.95
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/china-north-dumpling-san-francisco?select=1g75lAzSyjmMm7P2jSh3bg#4yE81GGRooZiWYQGK_gaFg)
Although they weren't as tasty as others I've tried (still good), it was awesome how they were so packed with filling.  I wonder if the ones with mushroom or chives would have been better, but these were still solid overall.

-- PAN FRIED DUMPLING...$6.95
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/china-north-dumpling-san-francisco?select=1g75lAzSyjmMm7P2jSh3bg#kpMtuyZ3pdrTKGisPAFoEw)
Like with the dumplings, every one of these was loaded.  In this case though, the filling was both savorier and juicier.  The bottom crust was the highlight though - the skin had the perfect consistency and the bottom was so nicely browned!

-- SHANGHAI STYLE CHOW MEIN (with Hand Made Noodles)...$7.95
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/china-north-dumpling-san-francisco?select=1g75lAzSyjmMm7P2jSh3bg#egMPX5J2nxWtfAjLDl3R1w)
Even though they aren't very long (perfect for kids though), the hand made noodles are a plus.  They had just slight bite to them, and the sauce on the noodles was terrific.  A little more meat would have been nice, but it was just fine otherwise.

-- HOUSE SPECIAL PORK...$8.95
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/china-north-dumpling-san-francisco?select=1g75lAzSyjmMm7P2jSh3bg#e6PEnwsgThYMy4kZcdF8Tw)
While all of the other dishes were good, this one stood out the most.  It was simple (pork belly, bok choy, and their house sauce), but well done.  The bits of pork were cooked perfectly (soft and tender) and I thought the sauce added a slight tartness to the dish.

Considering the three of us were able to try five things for a measly $40 (with leftovers), it's safe to say the portions at China North are both plentiful and cheap.  Which is a good thing too since between the various types of hand pulled noodle soups (particularly the spicy beef noodle soup) and all of the dumplings, there's plenty more to try!  About 155 or so, give or take.
author: Mike L.

description: Ordered for pickup through Eat24. Very easy, fast, and convenient. Usually I don't like ordering dumplings to-go but these held up great. Flavorful, hot, and not at all soggy. Chicken wings were very good and stayed crispy despite a to-go order.
author: Phil B.

description: Order delivery and my order was messed up. Instead of shrimp chow mean i got chicken and it looks like they didn't give me two order id the shrimp and chive dumpling even though i order two order. I don't eat chicken. I go here alot. Kind of sad. Guess i need to find a new place.
author: Sandy N.

description: I was really excited at first cuz I'm from north China but got super disappointed. The noodles are over boiled, many of the food are not even close to the taste of northeast. The service is even worse, waitress gave us super bad attitude when we asked for check (after sitting there for 30 min)
author: Xin Z.

description: The more I come here, the more I like this spot. I came here last weekend with my neighbors and we ordered egg and chive pockets, beef wrap, beef noodle soup, and sang jeen bao. It's always a satisfying meal. I have come here for some to-go items like beef wrap and chicken pancakes. I find myself craving this place sometimes. It's not a cheaper restaurant though.
author: Denise C.

description:
China 101 for some of these low review noobs.

- China North Dumpling is, [obviously] NORTHERN STYLE CHINESE FOOD.
 
- Typical northern Chinese cuisine consists of starchy foods like dumplings,  noodles, buns, and pancakes. If you want a real breakdown, it then varies from northeast to northwest by hand pulled noodles and the buns but I digress.

- Northern China = colder climate which = limited range of food that can grow. As a result = pickled goodies (think garlic, scallions, leeks etc in oil and vinegar) 

- meat consumed is primarily beef and lamb

So for you noobs who order garlic cucumbers and whine about oil, don't come here looking for chow mein or fried rice either.  CHINA NORTH IS NOT SHANGHAINESE. There are NO XLBs here noobs!

Complimentary peanuts and pickled cabbage upon seating. The pickled cabbage is spicy and tasty. 

China North Dumpling does indeed have a variety of dumplings. They offer them steamed or pan fried. My friends and I took so damn long we decided to order the 3 vegetable dumplings [fried] and the mushroom and pork dumplings [steamed]. 
Don't let the 3 vegetable dumplings fool you, it is not vegetarian because there is shrimp. China North only offers vegetarian dumplings on the weekends. 

The dumplings (both steamed and pan fried) were executed beautifully. Generous amounts of filling in the mushroom and pork especially. 

We shared an order of the beef pancake wrap. I was a little disappointed there was no sour cabbage inside of it (that's a-ok w/ me it's just what I've grown accustomed to) but happy that there was no cilantro. The pancake itself looked delicate because it was so thin, but it held up the beef and hoisin sauce that was already inside pretty well. The pancake was crispy. Definitely order this.

I had the spicy beef noodle soup w/ hand made noodles. Oh man. They gave me plenty of beef and there is PLENTY of noodles. The handmade noodles are thick and starchy (duh) and so filling. I LOVE THEM. They are cooked perfectly al dente and the spicy beef noodle soup broth is excellent. A good amount of cumin (totes normal for northern Chinese) and definitely hit the spot. 

I had a few bites of my friend's sesame handmade noodles. This is a cold noodle dish, and served with sliced cucumbers. Very refreshing but also filling because of the hand noodles. It would probably be best to share with another person. 
My other friend had the dumpling noodle soup (also with handmade noodles) which was good and plentiful. The dumplings in his order had minced shrimp in it so I didn't try. 

Total damage was about $50 and we had leftovers. 

I'm coming back to try more dumplings. Definitely don't shy away from the handmade noodles. The noodles and dumplings are made fresh here. I mean let's be real, you're not going to go to HOPR and order the fish right? Well don't be a feckin noob here either.
author: Susy C.

description: I'm putting it out there, this is my favorite restaurant of all time. The most authentic and delicious northeastern Chinese food I've had in North America. The flavors are absolutely spot on, each dish takes you to heaven. Truly unmatched by any other Chinese restaurant I've been to in terms of Northeastern authenticity. I live in South Bay and I come to this restaurant every time I visit San Francisco.
author: Kyle Z.

description: This is the best food in all of the Bay Area the only restaurant that we keep coming back to every time we are in the city they make their own noodles and dumplings right in the restaurant and the staff is super friendly if you have not eaten here you owe it to your taste buds.
author: Kevin C.

description:
Warning: If you are a fan of Orange Chicken, Broccoli Beef or other Chinese food you think that are real Chinese food, this is not for you.

Visited China North Dumpling with friends at a random afternoon to try some Northern Chinese food. I'm always a fan of Northern Chinese food, however, I can't stand for the heat. Le sigh. 

Dumplings, water boiled or pan-fried? You pick. I like it pan-fried because I can get that crispy warp mixing with the juicy meat melting in my mouth. I love lamb, especially when it cooks with cumin, nothing can beat cumin/lamb combo. I always get this feeling of wide field, grassy, windy in my mind when I have Cumin Lamb. Literally it's like experiencing the wild grass field... with the awesomeness in my mouth. LOVE. Water Spicy Fish is less spicy than I thought, and it's yummy, with a fresh taste of the fish (no idea what kind of fish it is) covered with spicy coat (imagining the spiciness as a rice paper wrapping spring roll with flavors,... here you go), nice balance.
author: Leslie C.

description: 3.5 stars, rounding up cause portions are huge!  Above average northern Chinese spot.  The dumplings were the best thing - had pork and chive, steamed.  Very large, perfectly cooked skin (tiny bit chewy), and good meat ratio.  The inside also had some soup in it as well and was not too salty which I love.  The spicy beef noodle soup had potential - hand pulled noodles and numbing pepper sichuan broth.  Beef itself was decent, generous portions, but was disappointed that the noodles just weren't QQ/al dente.   Had the sautéed pea shoots in garlic which was too salty and a tiny bit on the stringy side (produce quality issue).  Would come back again if in the hood!
author: Olivia T.

description:
This restaurant has an amazing selection of dumplings. To date, I've tried 13 out of their 21 types. As many other reviews have said, if you want good XLB, go somewhere else. That's not the point of this restaurant (which focuses on NORTHERN Chinese cuisine). Try the pork with napa cabbage or the pork with bok choy steamed, or try the chicken and corn pan fried. Absolutely fantastic. They're always making something, and if you ask what they're making and it sounds good, order that--the fresh stuff is awesome. 
Out of the 13 types of dumplings I've tried, I'll steer clear of the XLB and the pork with green pepper, but all of the other ones I've tried have been excellent. Looking forward to ordering the Shanghai hand pulled noodle soon.
This restaurant is quite inexpensively priced, and the waitstaff is timely and friendly.
author: Allxie C.

description:
Meh... 

We saw that this spot had just grand opened so decided to come here on Sunday night for dinner with the fam bam. 

Dishes we ordered... dumplings, pan fried potstickers, seafood fried rice, dan dan noodles, green onion pancakes, and pig heart. The dishes we wanted, they didn't have... yet, it's a dumpling spot. The food was either too bland or overly seasoned. Yuck. And hours after dinner, we were all super thirsty. MSG at it's finest. 

Let's see... service was horrible. Our waitress was rude and didn't even bother smiling whatsoever. It's obvious she didn't want to be there. We had to ask her for ice water three times. And when we were ready to pay, no one paid any attention... because yah, they were that busy... 

Needless to say, we won't be back.
author: Ann T.

description:
Ordered delivery from this spot and thinking it's my new go-to! Got the Hot & Sour soup ( texture was good but not much heat and a bit bland), Shanghai style noodles (delicious! Hand made noodles were thick and had bite and dish wasn't too salty), Cabbage & Pork dumplings (DELISH! Juicy and flavorful).
Overall, I was quite happy. Wouldn't order the hot & sour again, but delivery was prompt and the other two dishes were a hit.
author: Olivia B.

description:
2 1/2 stars. 

Not on point. 

Some guy from SFGATE just wrote an article about how bomb these dumplings are. I'm a huge dumpling fan and knew I needed to try these dumps ASAP. The SFGATE article made these dumplings sound heavenly. They were totally disappointing. It truly makes me question his dumpling palate. 

I've experienced my fair share of delicious dumplings and Northern Chinese cuisine. This place doesn't make the cut. The string beans were standard. Not as tasty as my go to Shanghai restaurant. The D5 and D8 dumplings lacked agreeable flavor, satisfaction, zest and care in their preparation. 

I understand that when you take out food there is a chance that it won't taste as good or be in tact once home. I live five minutes away, have a car and garage to park it in. Almost all of my dumplings were busted open when I got home. Yes, dumplings burst. I get it. That's normal for 2-3 dumps max. But almost all 24 dumplings busted within five minutes of driving? Not cool.

It should be noted that my rating also includes service. Upon ordering the staff said the wait time would be 20 minutes. Cool. Standard. 30 minutes roll by, then 40 minutes. It took 45 minutes for me to receive my take out order. I rush straight home to find ALL of the dishes I ordered to be luke warm. It's one thing to wait for perfection. But to double my wait time and bestow me with luke warm food is undeserving. 

Prices are good for the dumpling portion. However, I'm definitely going to pass on this restaurant in the future.
author: Rosalyn W.

description:
Wow this place was bad. We had been walking all day and were starving. We wanted to eat something as soon as possible. There was four Asian food places on the street we were on and all had three and a half stars. We knew that wasn't a good sign but we figured since there were so many places on the same street that they couldn't be that bad. Wrong 

I chose this place and it sucked. We got the wonton soup, the Kung Pao and the chive and prawn dumplings. 

It all sucked. The Kung Pao was soggy and bland. I can see why they call them chive and prawn dumplings and not the other way around cause I didn't see very much prawn, just a lot of chives. As for the soup, the meat in the won tons tasted rancid, my girlfriend and I were both surprised we didn't get sick. 

Very bad meal, oh and they were rude too.
author: Joe F.

description: It is a very traditional Chinese restaurant. It is on the 19th avenue. A friend highly recommended the restaurant. The environment is nice and the waiters are so kind. There are various kinds of food, such as pancakes, noodles, rice and so on. I ordered shredded beef roll, vegetarian dumpling, preserved veg shredded pork noodle soup. The dumplings are delicious. Others are just so so.
author: Nancy S.

description: A very good Dong Bei / Northern Chinese place. They have a great pickled cabbage lamb soup, cold tofu cucumber dish, and meat pancakes. Lots of great spicy dishes. We've hit this place a few times over the years, and it's always been pretty good. But seems like lately they might have gone a little down hill. Let's see if maybe our last visit was just a one time fluke.
author: Peter K.

description: Food here is pretty good, not overly greasy and salty. Menu is simple to read with pictures, 3 waitresses on a Friday night. Prices are also very reasonable with good portions. Had the beef stew handmade noodle, would recommend if you like spicy, a little on the salty side. Also had the silky tofu and fish, very simple and light plate.
author: Angela L.

description: The food here is excellent. Sometimes the dumplings are broken, and once we got a different kind than we ordered, but it is always good, and usually perfect. +1 for their house chili sauce.
author: James C.

description: Been here twice; good inexpensive comfort food, and haven't had to wait. Green onion pancakes are nice and crispy and chewy, the big pan fried pork dumplings (shui jian bao) are solid, good noodles, and more. The only let down we had was the pork belly with the bok choy - it looked nothing like the picture, with the pieces being smaller, darker, and tougher than expected. Those will not melt in your mouth, unfortunately.
author: Linus W.

description:
Despite the "health warning", we ate here again. 
I see how they got tagged for openly preparing dumplings on a large table just behind the counter. Chinese restaurants been doing this ever since I can remember. 

Ordered 
1. Spicey beef noodle soup. Plenty of chunky tender beef, hand pulled noodles, and a rich spicy broth. This was hit enough to just get my nose running and light sweat building. This soul was very very good. 
2. Spicey chicken. Small bites of chicken lightly battered mixed with a spicy garlic and smothered in red chili peppers. The chicken was seasoned just right and was crispy. Mmmmmmmmmm...
3. On a friend's recommendation, we tried the lamb dumplings, panfried. OMG. Fricken' yummy! Big plate, nice lamb flavor, and juicey. You can dip it in the variety if sauces on the table,  or just eat then as is. Full of flavor.
author: brian k.

description:
My friends and I were originally planning to go to Thai Nghiep Ky Mi Gia, but it was closed, so we had to had choose somewhere nearby; we ended up here.

The menu had lots of stuff, but since this place specialized in dumplings, of course we had to get that. And instead of the regular boiled ones, we decided to get the pan-fried ones because I hadn't had that elsewhere. We ordered the Beef/Celery and the Fennel/Pork Dumplings. For a main dish, we wanted something not too meaty, so we got the Egg Surface Tofu. And to pack on them carbs, we got Dalu Noodles. 

1. Beef/Celery Dumplings: This was a very interesting combo. I've never had beef dumplings before, so I was pleasantly surprised by the tender meat inside. 

2. Fennel/Pork Dumplings: The fennel had a pretty sensational aftertaste that lingered in your mouth. Who knew dumplings had that kinda power?

3. Egg Surface Tofu: This was the crowd-pleaser among my friends. It supposedly required 40 minutes to make, which I don't know if that is true because I feel like it was ready in 20. Anyway, it was silky and had a layer of crunchy batter in the middle. Yum.

4. Dalu Noodles: As someone who has eaten a ton of noodles, I've never had noodles quite like these. They were thick, but not super doughy. Also the gravy that topped it was really nice.

The service, of course wasn't great. We were kinda rushed to order our meal, and my friend said the workers were "mean-mugging" us the whole time. But for such a delicious, satisfying feast, it was only 30-something bucks between 3 people.
author: Alex Y.

description: Literally the worst  Chinese food I ever tried....the thickness of the shredded potatoes is like a pencil...I really don't know what to say... waste $30 for nothing...
author: HE H.

description:
Good prices and good service.  Dishes are huge, watch out.

Silk tofu with fish fillets - awesomely huge and smooth soft texture in tofu and fish

Lion's head meatballs - 4 bigass balls seasoned well with bok choy on the bottom

Vegetarian dumplings - basket steamed, a bit dry in the ingredients, since no meat, some soup inside would make it fantastic.  Clean and healthy.

Chives and shrimp dumplings - water boiled.  No mistakes.

Shanghai hand made noodles - thick short chewy noodles, kids favorite.

HK steamed white rice top with wet scramble egg and shrimp.  Lightly cooked egg in small amount of chicken stock with shrimp.  Wet, lightly tasty egg and shrimp, my favorite.  Can be ordered with chicken, pork or beef but shrimp is the OG choice.

Will be back to try some pork dumplings (boiled), pot stickers and any other type of noodles.
author: Kevin L.

description:
I went back last night and found my new favourite...the House special meatballs. The texture is unbeatable and having had to try to make this dish myself at home, I know that this kind of texture is time consuming and difficult to execute. These were perfect. The meatballs were juicy, soft, and not greasy at all and the baby bok choy that is often an afterthought was tenderly prepared and extremely flavourful. 

Don't forget the spicy wontons on the side as well. Insanely good! 

You know what else is awesome though? We came in relatively late-ish expecting to just get things to go, but Jophie (sp?) the sole hostess/server/runner extraordinaire in charge of the restaurant was super kind and accommodating and let us stay and eat way beyond closing time. Definitely a class act and makes me happy to keep patronizing the place.

Can't wait to try more from the menu and keep reporting back!
author: Clarissa S.

description:
We wandered here on a Sunday night, happy to find a business that's open, and clogged with people.  Tried the Northern cuisine and the verdict is:  I would happily seek this place out.  Delectable!

We ordered: 
Braised tofu with Mushroom:  tofu was soft and flavorful, mushrooms clearly fresh, not rehydrated.  Brown sauce was light, gingery.  
Winter melon with dried shrimp:  cooked til the flesh of the melon sunk beneath your teeth.  Sauce again was light and flavorful, not at all greasy. 
Pork & fennel dumplings: my partner reported "fresh, with a strong fennel taste" 
Vegetarian dumplings:  I loved that they steamed up the room.  I'll try them tomorrow. 

The wonderful flavors, freshness of the veggies, and the light touch won me over.  It's a neighborhood gem, tucked away from high prices and snooty people.  Will happily come back here!

Specialty are dumplings:  assorted new dumpling flavors line the walls.  

Pickled cabbage & roasted peanuts for starters
author: Emma R.

description: I order delivery and i told them to call me when the food arrive. The restaurant (not the delivery guy) called me and i told them to leave it by the door. After 1 min when i go pick up the food i heard the delivery guy speaking Chinese talking to the phone in a aggressive way that is so loud and i can heard him complaining about me when i was 20 feet away from the door which make me really mad. i open the door and he looked at me(kinda mad) asking me why didn't I pick up the phone ( which i never received from him). i told him that i never received his call, all i receive is a call from the restaurant and i already told her to tell him to leave the food by the door and i will pick it up. He still tried to argue with me witch makes me really mad because don't talk shit about me when your on your phone and don't talk to me in a rude way when there's something wrong with you guy's communication and don't argue with me when it's you guy's fault.
author: Mabel M.

description:
the salt n peppa chicken is the best version on this side of town. non greasy chunks of chicken meat on a healthy bed of red chili peppers. 
the spiciness is just right.
another great option here are the dumplings which are freshly housemade. 
although the wrapper is slightly thicker than my personal preference, it's still very good. another real winner is the fish fillet in chili oil. think numbing hot and get ready for awesome Northern style Chinese food.
they take credit cards, somewhat rare in a Chinese restaurant.
and plenty of street parking.  the staff is friendly and service is better than the average Chinese restaurant. I work in the area and this place may become my go to spot very soon. JYW likes!
author: Jeff W.

description: I like this place.  My cousin introduced this restaurant to me a couple of years back.  Their house noodles are great.  Freshly made.  The broth is tasty.  Their steamed pork leek dumplings are my favorite.
author: James L.

description:
Amazing! This is the second time I ordered from here. The egg rolls are great! They are fast on delivery and very polite. The first time, they forgot a part of my order and immediately called me before I could call them. They made it right, which is great of restaurants around here.

Would highly recommend!
author: Jeremy T.

description:
Came here with my wife & a friend for lunch today. We arrived at around 1:30pm. It was half full & everyone was already eating. We ordered within 10 mins after being seated. Since we haven't met this friend in months, we'd a lot of catching up to do. We kinda lost track of time. 

Half an hour later, we realized that the food we ordered weren't served. The restaurant was almost empty by then. We spoke to the server & she later found out that the kitchen lost our order. 10 mins later, all our food arrived, main dish first, followed by appetizer. The food has lots of MSG and my friend was very unhappy that they served the appetizer after they have brought out the main dishes.

I am very disappointed with the service here. I was a server for 4 years. I would check on my customers and if they haven't gotten their food, I would check with the kitchen what's going on especially when the restaurant is almost empty.

Anyway, food's terrible here. We won't be back again, ever.
author: Jun N.

description:
China North Dumpling takes over the long vacated Ice House spot. 

menu had over 200 entrees: dumplings,  appetitzer, soups, noodles, sizzling patters et al. but no xiao long bao.

eats:
-west lake with lamb steam dumplings (10/7.95)
huge dumplings with very little filling inside
some lamb flavor, dumplings leaked, wateryy
pricey, 

-special beef noodle soup(7.95)
big round bland noodles, commercial, not hand pulled
beef tender not tough, bits of it, not chucks
soup base a little beefy, little msg tasted.

foodnotes:
-food pricey, not a good value
-food on bland side, little msg tasted 
service spotty, (no soup spoon given with soup)
-most of the staff spoke cantonese
-onion pancake looked like 10" pizza, very browned, thick
-not sure what their specialty is, it isn't dumplings, soups, nor pancakes.
author: Victor G.

description:
Meh...

This place has been open for about a month or so. I had a craving for dumplings so we decided to try China North Dumpling.  You would think dumplings are their specialty given the name of the restaurant.  Boy, were we fooled!

As we walked in, I already smelled the grease odor.  It was probably a sign to go elsewhere, but we decided to give the restaurant a try.


We ordered:

-Garlic Cucumbers:  Cucumbers are supposed to be healthy, right?  Well, you'll be in for a surprise if you order the garlic cucumbers here! As stated in my tip, the "sliced cucumber" had an exuberant amount of oil that gathered at the bottom of the dish.  It was so GROSS!  

-Pork Dumplings: Bland and tasteless

-Green Onion Pancake:  Thick and doughy!  There was no green onion taste!

-Chicken Chow Mein:  I took a bite and had to spit it out!  It was sweet!  When did chicken chow mein become a sweet dish?  We informed our waitress who then took it back to the kitchen.  I guess the cook accidentally grabbed the sugar instead of the salt.  The dish was remade and tasted like what chicken chow mein should taste like. However, it was way too oily.

For a restaurant that wasn't busy, there was a significant wait time between finishing the first 2 dishes and getting our chicken chow mein.  When we left, our clothes and hair wreaked of grease.  Needless to say, I WILL NOT return.

Note to the owner if you're reading this:  please fix the ventilation in your restaurant!
author: Candice H.

description:
Came here with my dad for lunch and we both agreed this was one of the worst places we've eaten. Ordered black bean noodle, garlic string beans and dumpling. 

Black bean noodle - no taste 
String beans - tasted like raw garlic and was old 
Dumplings - just a bad taste 

Would I come here again? Nah.
author: Franci C.

description:
Really wanted to love this place, but the waitress in glasses was super bitchy towards our young ones. Granted we did have 3 noisy little ones, but the things that came out of our waitress's mouth were pretty astounding. Such as "Oh my God such bad children", I will take away their food now as they look like they are about to make a mess and give me more work" and my personal favorite: "Oh you're leaving? Good." Bear in mind that we had been very courteous to her the entire time. 

Utter bewilderment; happy to take my money elsewhere.
author: S T.

description:
my family and I always come here if we want easy Shanghai food ( if you're not Chinese, this is probably what you know as dumplings etc. ) 

there usually isn't a wait for a table, it's easily accessible ( space between tables and a large bathroom) for my grandma, who's in a wheelchair. the food is good, we always get the clear glass noodles with the fish and peppers. their regular Shanghai food is also good, like the  Napa cabbage pork dumplings, and the thin bread with beef sandwich. 

the service is also "doing their best". I always see the same two waitresses here every time I come; they don't talk much but they're very quick and get the job done. 

10/10 recommend
author: Serena L.

description:
Free wifi for customers.

Excellent value on the food, eg:

Onion pancake is $5 and is a full meal size for 1 person or appetizer for 4-6 people. 

Fried rice is $7 -- huge plate.  They made it gluten-free for my wife.  (Ask to omit soy sauce.)

Waitresses speak 3 languages: Mandarin Chinese, Cantonese, English
author: George K.

description:
This is a go-to spot for my boyfriend and I for both dine-in and take-out. It gives me that comforting homey feeling reminiscent of my grandmother's home-cooked Chinese food. We love that they open late and the service is super fast. 

Our favorite is the Preserved Vegetable with Pork and Handmade Noodle Soup. We might be the only ones who order it so much because the waitress knows what we want when we come or recognizes the order when we call in. This dish just warms my stomach and is full of flavor. 

Second on my list is the Shanghai Style Chow Mein. It's made with their handmade noodles, chicken, shiitake mushrooms, and some green onion. Absolutely delicious!

Other Recommendations: 
- Pork and Napa Cabbage Dumplings*
- Chicken and Corn Dumplings*
- Sliced Cucumbers
- Crispy Salt and Pepper Chicken
- Hong Kong Style Shrimp and Scrambled Egg Over Rice
- BBQ Pork and Shrimp Fried Rice

*I prefer to order the dumplings steamed, but I'm sure they're just as tasty pan fried.
author: Sharon L.

description:
Everything here was okay. I've been to a lot of dumpling houses in San Francisco, and typically you will get one item that is amazing, and everything else is meh. So you go to different places for different items you might be craving.

But this place, everything was good, not great, but good. Not a bad item at all.

So this place was just consistently good. Not disappointed, but probably won't come if I am craving dumplings.

Bonus points for this place though. They are open til 10pm (even on Tuesday nights when most restaurants seem to be closed)!
author: Eric C.

description:
Had hand pulled jah jurg mein. Nice texture, chewy, but flavors were just okay.
Soup noodles were even springier, but less flavor, even though it was the spicy beef.

The complementary peanuts and garlicky kimchee are nice to start with.
author: E. W.

description: The best. Amazingly tasty. I've enjoyed their vegetarian dumplings twice now and I feel an addiction is soon to follow.
author: Lisa F.

description:
Shanghai food so near my house, I wish this place was better.
The green onion pancakes were the thick bready kind, but hardly any onions in it.  The beef noodle soup was pretty bland.  And the chives pancake I got was too salty with way too much chives but hardly anything else.  To balance it out, I dumped a bunch of chives and put them on the green onion pancakes.  Now that was perfect.
author: Karen L.

description:
"Terrible service, foreign object in the kimchee and blah tasteless food"

I came here for dinner with family for the first time based on several folks saying how great this place was coupled with the fact that they were recently written up in the San Francisco Chronicle.

Unfortunately, the stars started to drop after we were seated. Arriving at 5:45 pm, the place was empty as it was on the early side for dinner and only three tables were occupied including ours. There were several servers with one hand preparing the pot stickers  two tables away from us. I literally had to do jumping jacks to get someone's attention letting them know we were ready to order.

With that being said and our order placed, our server came back with a small ramekin of salted peanuts and their Chinese version of kimchee which were complimentary. Unfortunately, upon closer inspection as my wife was getting ready to grab a piece of the napa cabbage used in the kimchee a single strand of course black hair was standing up like a lone weed in the ground!  YUCK....Of course we brought it to our server's attention and she emphatically said "sorry."

Dishes that we ordered:

Spicy Beef Noodle Soup:  We all agreed this was the best dishes and the portion was big enough for four people. Noodles and beef were tasty as well as the spice (which was not as spicy as I thought it would be).

Green Onion Pancake: Blah - All dough and definitely lacked flavor. We had to dip it in the Spicy Beef Tendon dish juices in order to eat it.  We had four pieces remaining after we paid the bill. Kitchen needs to add more green onion in their pancakes or have a special dipping sauce to accompany this dish.

Spicy Beef Tendon Cold Platter: I have had better that my brother in law has made. It was probably the second best dish

Crispy Salt and Pepper Chicken:  Just so so. Didn't really stand out in my opinion. Kirin in the Richmond District is so much better. This dish just lacked flavor although the whole pieces of red chili were nice.

Pan Fried Pork and cabbage dumplings: Like many of the yelpsters - I have had better. Very disappointed in this dish as this is what this place is known for.

Shanghai Noodles with Pork: Okay - Yes , the noodles are hand made but again this dish did not stand out. The Napa cabbage mixed with this dish gave it a limp presentation wise and they could have chosen a more heartier green vegetable to make the presentation nicer.

In summary, I doubt that I will be coming back here again. On a separate note. We left after 1.5 hours only to find a line at the door. I still can't figure that one out but perhaps it the reasonable prices.
author: Richard H.

description: I always eating in here, I like noodles and dumpings, and soy milk very fresh. Pancake nice.
author: Xinya L.

description:
The flavor is much alike the Northen Chinese food in my memory. It is pretty rare to find such flavor in the bayarea, or in US. This is one of those will-come-back places. 

The reasons I give 3 stars is 1) ambience, the restaurant is like any other cheap, neighborhood place; 2) quality, it is just alright, still have a lot of room for improvement.
author: Lydia L.

description: This place is great!  We usually order a few dumpling dishes and a noodle dish but today we decided to try the rice w egg and shrimp, which turned out to be excellent. Their menu is quite extensive so drop in and pick up a menu since they don't have a website. Solid food for a great price plus free delivery.  Highly recommended.
author: wendy w.

description:
In the vicinity, pancake house or Shanghai kitchen offers better XLB dumplings.  Ordered it here and all the juice broke away from the dumpling.

Beef roll was not good, wrap too doughy and proportion of sauce to beef to cucumber did not blend well.

The spicy beef noodle soup was not spicy but sweet.
author: Ju D.

description: Amazingly delicious sesame chicken lunch meal. It's just so good. The wait can be up to 15 mins if the place is crowded so I would recommend placing an order a bit in advance over the phone. Otherwise, no complaints
author: Tristan S.

description: Shockingly surprised at the quality of their food. Everything we ordered had great flavor. Portions were generous...dumplings 15x in an order. Only thing that would have made this a 5-star review would be the service. It wasn't bad, just unorganized and slow. But since they are less than a month old, I'm sure they'll run more smoothly very shortly.
author: Stephen Y.

description:
Went in on a Friday afternoon with my mother. The restaurant was pretty empty and there was only a table of 3 in the restaurant next to ours. The waitress was loud and sounded very impatient when we asked her if the dumplings were steamed or pan fried. 
   Green onion pancake- As others have mentioned, the pancake is thicker than other restaurants! The pancake was crispy and the green onion to pancake ratio was decent. This is def. the best part of the meal. 
  Chives pancake- This pancake looks like a giant pan fried dumpling!! There's 4 "pancakes" that's served on a plate and they are fried to golden perfection. They are stuffed with a very very generous amount of chives and a egg filling. One bite will cause the filling to overspill out of the pancake! Despite the crazy amount of filling, there were patches that were really salty or really bland throughout the pancakes! A def. no-no!!
  Chicken and cabbage dumpling-  We asked for these to be steamed and was not disappointed! The skin was perfect and the filling was juicy! However, there really wasn't much flavor to the dumplings. 
  Shrimp and chives dumpling- We requested for these to be pan fried and regretted it!! The dumplings were super oily and the skin began to taste funny. The filling tasted mainly of chives and there was little to no shrimp in the dumplings!! Very very upsetting, especially since I was expecting atleast ONE shrimp per dumpling! Lol
author: Celina C.

description:
Great Chinese food that is different from your normal fare. The homemade Shanghai noodles are delicious and the savory pancakes are huge. I haven't taken the dumplings to go yet but plan to and will surely update my review.

The reason it's not 5 stars is because the hot and sour soup is pretty bad - just tastes like vinegar and bland spice. Also the spicy dishes are not spicy. Service is also just OK - not sure if it's because I'm white and don't speak Chinese which seems to get quicker service or if they're just distracted in general. 

Delivery is quick if you live in the area.
author: Greg Z.

description: Yummy! Great value and tasty. The Special Dinner includes 3 entrees, soup, and rice. You can also order dumplings for $5.50 instead of $8.95.  The portions are generous. I ordered a similar meal from Chang's Kitchen on Irving and the portions were puny in comparison.  We enjoyed the freshness and quality of the food. My only complaint is that the menu on Eat24 didn't specify that the deal comes with rice and soup.
author: Katherine S.

description:
3 1/2 Stars.
