I didn't order the green onion pancake, which I usually love because my friend said it was all dough and no flavor. I saw another table order this and that's what it looked like. Darn

The XLB is only ok. Had good flavor, but the skin wasn't that great. 

Skip on the beef pancake rolls. 

The things I would come back for:

-Pork and corn dumplings-juicy and flavorful
-Spicy fried chicken-little pieces of fried chicken. The more you eat, the spicier it gets. This is addicting. 
-Shanghai Noodles-thumbs up
-Bean curd with cucumber-refreshing and good flavors to cleanse your taste buds
-The special fried tofu with meat and bell peppers. Takes awhile, but this is super good. My favorite dish of the night
author: Karen H.

description: 3.5, a mix of shanghainese and other items.  loads of dumplings and noodles here of carb lovers.  wrappers a bit too think for handmade dumplings boiled but nice ingredient choices.  pan fried ones a little tastier thinner, and juicy.  beef roll ok.
author: Rob C.

description: I like their Shaio long bao but not a fan of their fried dumplings. Too big and flavorless. But I'm happy to find a dumpling shop in the area. Missing Taiwan
author: Tiff W.

description:
Food is decent but this place is dirty. I probably won't come back because of that for obvious reasons. It smelled like bathroom which is gross when you're trying to eat. Floors are black....bowls were dirty.   Just not a clean environment that you want to eat in. I guess it's like China!  Authentic!

Oh and then when I looked this up on Yelp it had a food safety warning!  Yuck!   Should've checked before we went in.
author: CR L.

description: My favourite dish is the Spicy Fish. Its pan fried with chilies - soooo yummy & melts in your mouth. The flavour is awesome. It's not on the regular menu, you have to special order it. They make great Dumplings here of course. The Shanghai Noodles are great & so filling. They serve everything with pickled cabbage. Stick with what they are known for - their staples - such as the dumplings. The pots of soup and noodle dishes also are quite good. I tried their food for a take-away and ordered some basic Chinese staples the first time round, cos I was craving Chinese food - and it was just okay. I had some Trader Joes dumplings in the freezer so I didn't order dumplings here but I did order a soup and a few a la carte entrees and they were just average. But I completely changed my mind after I had the Fish, ordered special dumplings, abd had the Shanghai Noodles!
author: Julian I.

description:
Just moved into the area and glad to have a restaurant like China north dumpling. We had the dinner special which was more than enough for just my girlfriend and I (should feed close to four people). We got the Mongolian beef (great with the small kick of spice), broccoli beef (pretty good), and the sweat & sour chicken (better than most other places). Pricing was fair to cheap for the amount of food. 

Definitely will have to go again and try to explore the rest of the menu (possibly the thing they are know for, dumplings) . People there are friendly and helpful as well.
author: Jose E.

description: If it's dumpling in the Parkside to Sunset neighborhood in SF there is one place so farthest been consistent and hasn't failed as many dumpling places have come and gone. China North has somehow survived and thrived and I'm glad e have places that Chinese folk just go, grub eat and casually head home. Like your neighborhood dumpling spot China North offers a good array of hand made dumplings, hand made noodles, and various northern Chinese dishes. Me and my friend came in for lunch one day and ordered pan fried pork dumplings, spicy beef noodle soup, pork noodle soup, and a green onion pancake. This place also makes a good amount of "jianbing" - 煎饼 too. So a good place in the neighborhood if you're in for dumpling .
author: Alex C.

description:
Seriously, I don't know what the hate is about.

Maybe the name is wrong, and therefore people are expecting something different. Expect that there will be spiciness. Expect pickles. Expect oil. Expect mouth-numbing peppercorns. These are staples of the Northern Chinese cuisine. 

So, expect dishes like the Szechuan style hot and spicy boiled fish. Expect hand-pulled noodles (the right amount of chewiness, too!). Expect dumplings.

This was a surprising find in a primarily Cantonese town, but boy do they deliver.

Don't come here on a calorie-watching diet, your brain-computer will explode.
author: Ben T.

description:
I've been on a dumpling and noodle kick (Shanghai and Beijing type of food). This place was mediocre. The noodle wasn't too chewy (got the shanghai noodles) and the spicy mustard picky noodle dish with pork was skimpy on the pickled mustard greens. 

I should of checked out the noodle place across the street instead.
author: Jboogie L.

description: This place is delicious. I got the beef stew lo-main with dumplings, was more than enough food. Smells great in here, and the staff is very polite
author: Mathew S.

description: Full disclosure: I don't think Chinese food in sf is anywhere near the level of the San Gabriel valley. Everything seems overpriced and very mediocre.  Having said that, this place is the closest ive encountered so far that approximates something in la. Many of the dumplings and baos were able to be customized because everything was made fresh. Something very rare these days. Prices were surprisingly reasonable too. I'm making this my new go to Chinese place in the city.
author: M C.

description: The amount of food for the pricing is pretty decent compared to other Northern Chinese places. My family ordered the lamb with cumin, the green onion pancake, the dumplings, hot sour soup, spicy beef soup, liver with spicy chilis, and the beef tendon with cucumbers and spicy oil. It was flavorful and definitely hit it off the spot. After reading the low reviews and other people's reviews, I definitely agree. Please do not come to a place like this and expect good fried rice or chow mein. Go to Panda Express for something like that. You should primarily get Beijing style food here rather than the typical typical.
author: Wesley K.

description: We just ordered from North China as it's X-Mas Eve and didn't want to cook. The Sweet and Sour Pork was -gray-! How is that possible? The mu-shu was fine, but everything else was so bad. Over spiced or no taste at all. -Never- will we order from them again.
author: Alex H.

description: Best dumpling place in San Francisco!!!  Anyone that is around the sunset area should try their dumpling at least once.
author: Michael P.

description: I was surprised that there was a "health warning" message on the yelp page for this place. I've been going there for delicious food for awhile now and compared to a lot of the Chinese restaurants around they clean. The dumplings are what you get here! Magic in your mouth! They also have some good main dishes and soups as well! I've never really had a problem with the service there, just realize that the service culture is a bit different than your average restaurant. Then again they make it up with the food so its okay!
author: Yas J.

description: Consistently great food! I love their handmade noodle soups, all various types of dumpling (pan fried or steamed), chicken pancake- just to list a few. Whenever I feel like making my friends jealous, I just send pics of the food from this place and they're instantly drooling for some!
author: Felicia F.

description:
4 stars only for the dumplings here.  They offer over 10 types of dumplings with a choice of steamed or pan-fried.  Ordered the pan fried  3 flavor vegetarian dumplings which consists of chives, eggs and shrimp.  And steamed Napa cabbage with pork which also has minced ginger inside.  Both kinds were delicious, fresh and juicy. They don't skimp on the filling and the best part was that the skin was not too thick. Comes with a sweet vinegar sauce.  Looking fwd to try the corn and chicken dumplings and the fish one! 

Also ordered the beef noodle soup with their handmade noodles. Yuck. I hate their noodles. Too thick and doughy for me. The soup was bland and the beef was not good. I will pass on this next time. 

The beef pancake roll was OK. I was hoping that the pancake was made with green onion but it was just plain.  Texture was not bad ...thin and slightly crispy.  Next time I think I will just order the green onion pancake.  No more fancy pancakes for me.
author: Cathy M.

description: Quite possibly one of the worst Chinese restaurants I've ever been to. Everything has ginger in it. Every dish was beyond greasy and bland aside from over powering ginger flavors. We had so much left over it was sad. The noodles were clearly over cooked and frozen.
author: elle f.

description: The dumplings are fresh! And the waitress are so friendly, I like their handmade dumplings, pancake, and their house kimchi!
author: Ciel S.

description: Tasty and unique cuisine from the north of China. Staff is friendly and really fun. Enjoyed our impromptu lunch/dinner
author: Arthur G.

description: This place is a real hidden gem! The flat beef pancake was delicious and I highly recommend, for the juices oozing out like a XLB yet crispy panfried thin skin and the flavours of the beef with onions was perfection. The noodles are all freshly handmade. So we also ordered a pork noodle stirfry which was not greasy like the typical chow mein. We also grabbed a beef noodle stirfry vegetable dish which came with the most tender beef. Lastly, the beef over egg fried rice was so good my kid ate it up. The dishes were large enough to share family style. And the service was polite especially on a busy Friday night, which they hustle to serve. I'm really glad that after all this time of walking pass this place I gave it a fair shot. I definitely plan on coming back. Oh they also provide two small complimentary sides of peanuts and spicy napa cabbage too.
author: Peachie Y.

description:
Love this place! I met up my friends at the bar across the street about dinner time. I wasn't planning to eat dinner but realized I was hungry when I got there. Sooo before I ordered drinks.. I went over to china north. My friend is a chef and can be picky but he told me awhile ago that the dumplings here are delicious. 
I looked on yelp and three things that caught my eye were: beef pancake (rolled up), spicy beef noodle soup, and steam dumplings. I walked in and saw that they were hand making the dumplings. I ordered everything I had my eye on and asked which dumpling was most popular.. She pointed at the first 7 or so items on the list. I went with the pork and chive dumplings. She said, "oh you came in perfect time.. They're making it right now!" 
Omg the dumplings were the star. Soo juicy and flavorful. I like it better than shanghai dumplings from all the other popular dumpling places. My friends were skeptical when they ate the dumplings but they said "omg that is bomb".. And it really was!  I really enjoyed my beef noodle soup and pancake. I love how the noodles were fresh and handmade.
Will definitely come back!.. Or more like have their delivery on my speed dial! LoL.

Oh and forgot to mention.. They were actually pretty nice and polite. I never expect that coming from a Chinese restaurant.. So that's another plus!
author: Jennifer D.

description: We came here after 9pm for our late dinner. The server came quick to order our food. We got the pork/corn dumplings (12 pcs.), beef noodle soup, and hot garlic sauce pork meat (appetizer). The portions of each dish was huge. My husband and I were so full afterwards. The food was okay, nothing special. The hot garlic sauce pork was not the best as I can taste that they pour hot sauce over the pork. The authentic one had a strong taste of the pork and the sauce combined together. Other than that, I think is not a bad place to grab a quick bite for dinner with large portions.
author: Elaine C.

description: Ordered the beef roll pancake,  pan fried corn and chicken dumpling, steamed pork and cabbage dumplings, spicy beef tendon,  and beef noodles. Waitress told us the pan fried dumplings would take 20 minutes.  We said ok,  it took over 20 minutes for anything to arrive.  Soup noodles were hand pulled, it was recommended by our waitress.  Soup based very bland, had to tweak it with vinegar and hot sauce.  The beef tendon had lots of garlic to it, only downside is the beef tendon was not tender at all. It was very chewy. dumplings were only so-so.  Service spotty, needed more waitress. Also if they streamlined the kitchen and supplies,  the wait might not be so long. Not sure if I will come back again.
author: Alicia A.

description:
Came here one night because my friend wanted to get some dumplings. Been to other dumpling restaurants in the city, and I was not impressed by this one. 

First thing was it was missing things like what I am used to at Kingdom of Dumplings, Shandong Deluxe, and others. They didn't have Xiao Long Bao, which I thought would be associated with this type of establishment. 

No choices of drinks, and only tea or soda. I am a big fan of the soy milk or something coconut. 

We were really mad because, we were seated, ordered a couple dishes, most of the items slowly came, but it seems like they forgot our dumplings. There was another table that came after us, and they got their dumplings. It was not like we had a complicated order, but they totally forgot about us. Each time we asked the waiter, she totally ignored us. She took our tea to refill, and did not come back with the tea, until I demanded some tea. 

I think going to the dumpling establishments on Taraval would be nicer and better tasting.
author: Jason H.

description: Got the Spicy Beef Noodle Soup, Wonton in spicy oil, and the green onion pancake as delivery. Read some past reviews about how the pancake was more of dough and had barely any green onions so I wasn't expecting anything. The ones that I got had a decent amount of green onions in them so I guess it depends per order. The wontons hit the spot and was sweeter than I expected (then again I eat Shanghai+Taiwan style more often). Spicy beef noodle soup was more of a meh for me (Too used to San Gabriel Valley and legit Taiwan night market stalls). Wasn't spicy enough to get my eyes watering and nose runny. Beef was slightly overcooked, but the noodles were pretty damn good. It's hard to find really good beef noodle soup in SF so I guess this will pass for my tastes. Overall, I'm pretty satisfied with what I got. Not sure if I would pay $20+ again for free delivery though.
author: Jessica C.

description: I ordered a few vegetarian dishes online and received a call shortly after. The lady on the phone said she noticed I ordered mostly vegetarian dishes, but that one dish contained shrimp and if that was okay. I clarified that I did not want any fish or meat and she kindly assured me it would not be a problem, she just wanted to double check. What a great first impression from this restaurant! I would've been super bummed out if I bit into my food and got a mouthful of shrimp. I really appreciate the extra consideration! Thank you!!
author: Brooke K.

description:
I came here last Thursday, five days after their grand opening.  This is one of two place within this block Noreiga Street with a "Grand Opening" banner up front (the other being The Crew, a Korean restaurant across the street).

For this type of restaurant, I would think their specialty would be the dumplings and the noodles.  I went for the dumpling that evening.  The one I ordered (I forgot exactly which one) was okay.  I think I had better ones of this style (northern type) at King of Noodles on Irving Street.  Also I was disappointed they didn't have shrimp and chives dumpling, my preferred type at places like this.

I also got the hot and sour soup even though it wasn't listed on the menu.  They charged me $4.95 on the bill and it was pretty good-sized portion for the price.  It's funny that the lady recommended I go to the Little Beijing Restaurant across the street and try their soup because her customer tells her it's the best one over there.  At least that's honesty.

The staff was pretty nice and talkative.  At least a couple of them speaks Cantonese, but from things I hear they' may be from Taiwan.

One day I'll go back and check out the noodles.
author: H K.

description:
Saw the Grand Opening sign so had to try this so I could be the first to review. Restaurant was operatin but the proprietress said real opening was not until tomorrow. 

There are chefs making dumplings right behind the counter so the dumpling looked really fresh. 

Ordered the
-Beef pancake
-Pan fried Fish dumplings
-Home style Bun (northern sweet and sour beef specialty as recommended by the staff)

Dumplings were phenomenal. 
Beef pancake was a little cold. 
Sweet and sour beef had good flavor and texture. 

I would come back for the dumplings.
author: Roland L.

description: Very tasty for a very reasonable price. The waitress & waiter are great and very nice. Will for sure come back!
author: Gogo W.

description: I did not know they felt the health inspection. Been here on sunday 6pm. Kinda busy for them .2 girls run the whole dining room. Sure this is short handed. I order kidney sautee was over cook. U know it will be hard and dry. Pancake was good. Sao lung bao just ok.
author: jerry l.

description: I was a bit lazy to cook yesterday and ordered for delivery. I ordered the shanghai style chow mein, pan fried baos, spicy beef noodles and their house special pork. Their chow mein with fresh hand pulled noodles was awesome, good flavor and just the right amount of chew in their noodles. I was disappointed in the baos and the spicy noodles. The flavor of the baos was a bit unusual from what I thought and the dough was a little on the heavier side. The spicy noodles was very greasy with chili oil! Their pork was good but nothing too special. Overall it was ok and I would probably order for delivery again on a lazy day.
author: Julie C.

description: We got here for lunch at 11 A.M. They were opened several minutes before business hour.  The service was good and fast.  We had the fish filet with silky tofu, corn with pork dumplling, vegetable Shanghai chow mein and house special meat balls.  The meat balls were huge.  I enjoyed the fish filet with silky tofu the most out of the four items.  Food here is above average to me.
author: Steve T.

description: First time trying this place.  I tried the wonton, dumplings, don don mein and cold plate... Noodles, dumplings skin were hand-made (not from a factory).  I like the most is the wonton.  The quality is good.. Price is reasonable.  Worth a try!
author: D F.

description: Terrible terrible service, I'll NEVER be here again, the waitress has terrible attitude and everything she's done is to write down our order and collect the check. Also, their dishes are terrible too, DO NOT get ANY of their suggestions!!! Wish there's a negative rating that I could choose.
author: Logan Q.

description:
Amazing food. The dumplings with lamb and vegetable are delicious. The spicy noodles with beef in soup is great. Any hand-pulled noodle dish will be excellent. 
In addition: wonderful, cozy restaurant. I love the curtains in the window. Extremely pleasant service.
author: Daphne X.

description: China North Dumpling Restaurant is an amazing traditional Northern China food restaurant. I like to eat dumplings and beef noodle in there. I have ever to eat the  good taste beef noodle soup around this area. It is the best one. Love it!
author: CoCo W.

description: The onion pancake barely had any onions. The dumpling was fresh but it could use more filling. MSG alert though, super thirsty after my meal.
author: J C.

description:
Solid 3 stars

Food: 3.5  stars.  

Great dumplings made fresh throughout the day (5stars).  

Noodles are made fresh by hand in a similar (if cruder) way to soba.  (3 stars)

Noodle soup tastes good, but stingy on sides---some token peices of beef for the spicy beef noodle soup (they got me the wrong order).  (2.5 stars)

Takeout is a major portion of their business.  There was a swarm of college age youngsters getting takeout.  

Service: 2 stars...maybe

I was ignored for twenty minutes trying to get a table.  A bowl of noodle soup took about 38 minutes.  The check came in 2 minutes.

I give 2 stars because the two waitresses looked like they were very understaffed.  


I have reservations about coming back, but the food is solid if unremarkable--I don't know if I gave them a fair chance.
author: Matt L.

description: Great place for authentic Sichuan. Ordered the Spicy Boiled Fish and Kung Pao chicken. Portions are huge so took the fish home. Delicious!
author: Dhruv L.

description:
China North Dumpling
located on Noriega in the Sunset district, across the street from Tiki's Bar basically. This new restaurant, well I think they haven't been open too long, is Shanghai type of food. There is XLB (juicy dumpling/xiu long bao), though I haven't tried because I didn't see it on the menu but it was posted on the left side of the wall. The restaurant itself have ample space, basically has space right when you enter (left side) and if you turn right, there's larger seatings available there. I ordered the pepper salt chicken (which is diced), spicy garlic eggplant, and also the flat beef noodle. First, the pepper salt chicken is amazing, came with lots of red chili peppers (fried extra crispy) which can be spicy, so be careful. I love spicy food so it was alright to me. This order of chicken was better than San Tung chicken to me, It was soo delicious that I can eat this once a week! haha, well that's my fatty inside splurting out crap. So, next is the spicy garlic eggplant. WARNING! when you first get this dish, prepare yourself! don't just grab it with your chopsticks and shove it into your mouth, because even though it's oily greasy deliciously flavorful eggplant is very tempting, it will BURN YOUR MOUTH. well, it was worth it, AHAHa. so, in all retrospect, this is by far one of the best restaurant that makes spicy eggplant. Awesomee....then came the beef flat noodles, nothing special really, I would go witht he hand tossed shanghai noodles next time, I heard it's better.
stop by if you're on Noriega or come by after a round of drinks, this place is definitely worth stopping for!
author: Hao B.

description: Just had to do an update because this is now our go to in the neighborhood for chinese food.  We have now tried the eggplant in garlic sauce and sautéed green beans.  Solid!  We go with the veggies, the shanghai hand-pulled noodles and an order of dumplings (pan fried now vs. boiled - terrific pan fried) and the whole family is happy.
author: lucy w.

description: Handmade noodles, Shanghai dumplings and very friendly waitstaff made for a very satisfying experience.
author: Michael S.

description: The restaurant that was here before was MUCH better.  All the dishes lacked spice and came off as really bland.  This place calls itself "China North Dumpling" but the restaurant which formerly occupied this spot, and didn't specialize in dumplings, made far superior dumplings.
author: Kelvin S.

description:
Came here to try out the new restaurant on the block.  With a name like China North Dumpling, one should hope that dumplings are their specialty but take a look at the menu and you just might realize you were wrong.  

- Green Onion pancake: large, thick and fluffy = very filling!, unlike the thin fried pancakes commonly found in Shanghai restaurants; had adequate amount of green onions and flavor.  
- Chives pancake: 95% minced chives, 5% eggs, I swear there's supposed to be pork in this; flavor is a-ok if you like chives chives chives.  
- Special beef noodle soup: pieces of beef and tendon atop thick noodles in broth; came to our table only a minute after we ordered so I assume this was pre-made and the waitress did tell us that the beef is added on after the noodles are done; noodles by itself were nothing special and I had to add hot sauce to keep from getting bored.  Beef was ok on its own, the tendon was soft and gelatinous the way I like it.  Broth was not bad, maybe a little msg in it?  
- West lake w/ Prawns Fried Dumpling:  What's West Lake, you ask? Oh, just zucchini.  High expectations for this because of its unique ingredients. This was very lightly fried and the dumpling skin seemed fresh and thin.  The interior, however, was disappointing; very little filling (grated zucchini and prawns), bland and soggy, maybe slightly overcooked.  When you cook zucchini, it tends to become a shrunken watery mess if not done right, and this probably contributed to the lack of flavor.  The prawns were diced up to a size smaller than my pinkie fingernail and each dumpling only had maybe 2 of these tiny pieces.  

There was a significant wait time between finishing the first 2-3 dishes and getting our dumplings.  Our clothes also smelled of grease/kitchen odors after we left, I don't usually expect this to happen unless I'm at kbbq.
author: Renee L.

description: Surprisingly this place was pretty amazing, especially as a food delivery service. Items arrived quickly and were still very warm/fresh. Don't let the name deceive you because weirdly enough, though they have dumplings in their name, their dumplings weren't the greatest. Everything else though was phenomenal. We order the pork buns(Pan fried Bao), which came in six total, and they were amazing! They were perfectly meaty and cooked to the perfection. We also ordered General Zoa's chicken (basically orange chicken) and it was so juicy and crispy. I recommend that plate for people not wanting to explore the Chinese food world and want something good and reliable. We also ordered, the best saved for last, their shanghai styled chow mien noodles (hand made) and they were one of the best chow mien noodles I've personally ever eaten. I recommend to go eat at this place if not order for delivery!
author: Jennifer M.

description: The broth that they have in here for their noodles are amazing, there are a lot of flavors on them and they also have amazing chicken dishes that are undeniably oriental.
author: Steve Y.

description: Waited 30 minutes for dumplings and waitress tells they overlooked dumplings and have to recook. Ridiculous
author: Betty C.

description:
Dumplings seem all the rage these days and here's another one to join the fray.  Unfortunately, it doesn't really add much to the scene.

It's new, it's clean, it's got some strange quirks -- each table has ONE laminated take-out style (folded in 3 parts), the tables are packed very tightly.

Service gets one star right now.  I chalk it up to a slow ramp up from the opening as they figure things out, but right now, it's just glaring even for a Chinese restaurant.  We didn't get a plate of peanuts/pickled veggies like every other table had (although I heard the next table complain their peanuts were not crispy...so maybe I got lucky?).  Never got any tea.  Took three requests to the frantic waitress to get some water.  Asked for bowls to share and didn't get any spoons.  The bowls of course...were dirty.  The table next to us got up and helped themselves to get silverware because they had none even though their food got brought out already (They quipped "I guess it's self-service...")

Food gets two and a half stars.  It's not bad.  It's not great.  But I wouldn't come back.

Beef noodles -- noodles were decent, very few pieces of beef, and the soup was barely flavored.  Overall, edible, but bland.

Vegetarian dumplings -- had filling of eggs and chive.  Again, decent.  Came out really water-logged from the boiling.  Skin is pretty thick and doughy.  Also kinda bland.

Beef pancake -- a barely there smear of beef, which makes you wonder where all the grease came from.  Barely seasoned.

I'll stick to Dumpling Kitchen on Taraval -- it's like night and day.
author: J M.

description:
Uh ... all I can say is MISS.  

Was in the area so saw the grand opening sign and decided to try, big mistake.  -First item we order, onion pancake, thick and full of nothing but dough.  

-Second, beef noodle soup.  The Soup was BLAND, like almost drinking water and a little msg.  

-Third, we also ordered the Mu Shu Pork (Something we normally don't).  Anyway, the "stuffing" for the wraps came, and it looked like in was baked in soy sauce, totally dark and salty.  Chef poured in way too much soy sauce! They also forgot to bring the wraps for the mu shu pork, so what did one of the waitress do?  She bought UNCOOK egg roll wrappers to give to us for the mu shu pork.  We all gave her the WTF look!?
    
-Our last item, the "Napa Cable with pork dumpling" ..... they bought chives and pork dumpling to us instead.  The dumpling place next door makes better dumpling you can buy to bring home to cook.  

Anyway, the last place that opened up in this spot went belly up not too long.   This isn't going to stay in business very long either with they way it's run and way below par food.
author: Guess G.

description: Bf and I ordered the special beef noodle soup and pork and cabbage dumplings. I thought the noodle soup was decent but bf said it only tasted like MSG. Dumplings were bland. No xlb at this place for those xlb lovers like me.
author: W W.

description: I was headed home to the South Bay after a visit to the De Young and stopped here for a snack since it's just off 19th Ave.  I just ordered mushroom pork fried dumplings to try.  They were very good.  I'll have to go back on the next trip to the museum to try out the onion cake and other dishes which looked very good -- I always look at other people's food.  The smells, which contribute so much to the taste of food, were also very good.
author: Jane W.

description: Good price, large portion, decent food! The special dinner deal (to go only) is perfect for being lazy to cook.  Only $20.95, get to pick 3 dishes from selected menu, comes with sour & spicy soup and rice.  I got the beef with green onion, spicy fish, and eggplant with garlic sauce. It was plentiful for 7 people.  The spicy fish was surprising good.  I was just expecting fillets with chilly sauce over it, but to my surprise, it was deep fried fillets with dried crush pepper and red whole chilly peppers.  It was delicious!  Other food are ok, dumplings are fresh, green onion cake is flavorful.  Potstickers and noodles are just so so.  Overall, very good price for decent food.  However, food are served pretty slow.
author: Jen C.

description: Our new go-to spot for authentic Beijing cuisine! We always order a feast when we dine here - reminds us of our many trips to China. Service is excellent; the girls are very nice and attentive (and multilingual - they speak English, Cantonese, Mandarin, plus other dialects too!). Highly recommend the pancakes, crispy spicy chicken, Shanghai style hand-pulled noodles, walnut prawns, egg and tofu, lamb noodle soup, and Shanghai dumplings. You can have the dumplings steamed or fried like potstickers - I recommend getting them fried. All super yummy!  Highly recommended - thumbs up!
author: Christine S.

description: Fresh Noodles & Dumplings!!! Great for families & plenty of options for the kids. The BBQ Pork soup w/ house made noodles rocked!
author: Jason K.

description:
Very fresh dumplings. The chef is from the Shandong area in China. Their name is translated "water dumpling" For those less knowledgeable, their specialty would NOT be XLB, which is a Shanghainese dish. 
The Mushroom with Pork Steam Dumpling was very fresh, had a good amount of quality filling and a good skin. The garlic sweet vinegar gave the correct "ethnic" touch to the dumplings. You can request black/Chinkiang vinegar, but not surprisingly, their garlic vinegar was the better match. The black vinegar imparted too much of its own flavor and "unbalanced" the dish. An excellent selection!
Their Chicken w. House Special Brown Sauce also used good, fresh ingredients. Good spicy flavor with a bit of Sichuan Pepper. A touch too much oil, but still very good.
The more pedestrian MuShu Chicken (in this case) had good ingredients, did not flood the plate or wrappers with a ton of liquid, and was not over salted. The wrappers were the correct, very thin Popiah variety. A good choice, even though it is not a dish from their region.
The Green Onion Pancakes were not great. We saw them making them fresh there, but they were just not light enough. Good if you wanted a heavy dish, but sadly, not a good example of what they should be.

Service was ok. Friendly but understaffed at first, but as more wait staff materialized, it was pretty responsive. In summary, I absolutely would go back. Good quality, unigue dishes with an enthusiastic and polite manager.
author: Art Y.

description: silky tofu and fish soup - the dish that makes me keep coming back! by far, the dish that is a requirement when I come here. the dumplings are handmade, the service is great, staff that can start and maintain a conversation with its patrons. thank you very much and keep up the great food, I will return!
author: Jossy W.

description: My friend and I found this place by chance.  It was between this restaurant and another restaurant a few doors down and we selected China North Dumpling.  That was a few weeks ago and we have been back at least 4 or 5 times.  The food is absolutely delicious.  For appetizer we've had both their green onion and sesame pancakes-both delicious.  The pot stickers which are house made are plump and juicy.  However it does take the kitchen about 20 minutes to prepare them and the server was nice enough to let us know.  For cold platter we had the slice cucumber which is recommended if you order a spicy dish. For meat, we had the crispy salt and pepper chicken which was not greasy and had a little heat.  The cumin lamb is my favorite but be careful and tell the server to tone down the heat..  For vegetables we have had the spicy cabbage but my favorite is salt and pepper tofu.  Instead of rice, try the Shanghai Style Chow Mein.  The noodles are hand made in the restaurant.  Also, if its not on the table ask your server for their house made sweet chili sauce.  Great for the pot stickers or the tofu dish.  We've become almost regulars here and we look forward to our next visit.  Maybe we will try something new like their wonderful house made dumplings.
author: David P.
